content.title: Inhaler Technique
content.summary: Proper use of inhaled medication delivery devices including metered-dose inhalers (MDI), dry powder inhalers (DPI), and nebulizers for effective drug delivery to the respiratory tract
key_points: Proper technique essential - poor technique is common cause of treatment failure
MDI requires slow deep inspiration with breath-hold; spacer improves delivery
DPI requires fast forceful inspiration - DO NOT use spacer with DPI
Spacer recommended for MDI with ICS to reduce oropharyngeal deposition
Nebulizer for patients unable to coordinate or generate adequate inspiratory flow
Observe and correct technique at every visit - deteriorates over time
Different devices require different techniques - don't assume competence

statement.text: Effective inhaler technique is critical for drug delivery to the airways. Metered-dose inhalers (MDI) require slow, deep inspiration followed by breath-hold; using a spacer improves lung deposition and reduces oropharyngeal side effects. Dry powder inhalers (DPI) require fast, forceful inspiration to disperse the powder. Nebulizers deliver medication as a mist for patients unable to use handheld devices. Poor technique is a major cause of treatment failure in asthma and COPD.
statement.formal: MDI technique = Shake | Exhale fully | Seal lips | Actuate while inhaling slowly (3-5 sec) | Hold breath 10 sec | DPI = Exhale away | Inhale fast and deep | Hold breath

explanation.intuition: Inhaled medications work by depositing drug particles directly onto the airway surface. If particles are too large or the breathing pattern is wrong, drug deposits in the mouth and throat instead of the lungs. MDIs spray medicine with propellant - you need to inhale slowly so particles can travel deep into the lungs. DPIs use your breath to carry powder - you need to inhale fast and hard to pick up the medicine.
explanation.key_insight: The optimal breathing pattern is OPPOSITE for MDI vs DPI. MDI = slow and steady (3-5 seconds) to let propellant evaporate and particles decelerate. DPI = fast and forceful to generate enough turbulence to disperse powder. Teaching this difference is crucial when patients switch devices.
explanation.technical_details: Particle size determines deposition site. 1-5 μm particles reach lower airways; larger particles impact in oropharynx. Spacers allow propellant evaporation and particle deceleration, improving lung deposition from 10-20% to 20-40%. MDI-spacer delivery is equivalent to nebulizer for most patients with adequate technique.

definitions_glossary.metered_dose_inhaler: Pressurized canister delivering measured drug dose via propellant (HFA)
definitions_glossary.dry_powder_inhaler: Breath-activated device delivering drug as fine powder
definitions_glossary.spacer: Holding chamber attached to MDI that improves drug delivery and reduces side effects
definitions_glossary.nebulizer: Device that converts liquid medication into mist for inhalation over several minutes
definitions_glossary.oropharyngeal_deposition: Drug depositing in mouth and throat instead of lungs - causes local side effects
definitions_glossary.breath_hold: Pause after inhalation allowing particles to deposit in airways
definitions_glossary.inspiratory_flow: Speed of air intake during inhalation; affects DPI drug delivery
definitions_glossary.soft_mist_inhaler: Propellant-free inhaler creating slow-moving mist (e.g., Respimat)
definitions_glossary.actuation: Pressing the MDI canister to release a dose
definitions_glossary.priming: Spraying doses into air to prepare new inhaler
definitions_glossary.oral_candidiasis: Thrush caused by ICS depositing in mouth - prevent by rinsing
definitions_glossary.spacer_valve: One-way valve allowing inhalation but preventing exhalation into spacer

pathophysiology.mechanism: Inhaled drugs must reach the target site (bronchial smooth muscle, inflammatory cells) to be effective. Drug deposition depends on particle size (1-5 μm optimal for lower airways), inspiratory flow rate, and breathing pattern. Proper technique maximizes lung deposition; poor technique wastes medication and causes side effects.

mdi_steps: Start slow inhalation, press canister while continuing to inhale
dpi_steps: Seal lips, inhale fast and deep
common_errors: Breathing too fast (MDI) or too slow (DPI)

device_selection.mdi_spacer: First choice for most patients; equivalent to nebulizer
device_selection.dpi: For patients with adequate inspiratory flow who prefer no spacer
device_selection.soft_mist: Alternative for patients with poor MDI coordination
device_selection.nebulizer: For severe exacerbations, young children, elderly with poor coordination or low inspiratory flow

patient_education.demonstration: Show proper technique, have patient demonstrate back
patient_education.reassessment: Check technique at every visit - it degrades over time

definition.@value: Proper use of inhaled medication delivery devices to maximize drug deposition in the respiratory tract

skos.scopeNote: Covers MDI, DPI, and nebulizer technique for asthma and COPD management
skos.example: A patient with poorly controlled asthma despite ICS therapy is found to be actuating MDI before inhaling and not using a spacer; technique correction results in improved control

learning_objectives: Demonstrate proper MDI technique with and without spacer
Contrast MDI vs DPI optimal breathing patterns
Identify common technique errors that reduce efficacy
Select appropriate device based on patient capability
clinical_pearls: MDI = slow and steady (3-5 sec), DPI = fast and forceful - opposite patterns!
Spacer with MDI/ICS essential to reduce thrush and improve delivery
NEVER use spacer with DPI - defeats the purpose
Always observe technique - ask patient to demonstrate, don't just ask if they know how
Rinse mouth after ICS to prevent candidiasis
Nebulizer not superior to MDI-spacer if technique is correct
common_misconceptions: Nebulizers are more effective than MDIs (false - equivalent with proper technique)
All inhalers use the same technique (false - MDI and DPI are opposite)
Patients know how to use their inhalers (false - technique errors extremely common)
